Yeah sure it's hella easy.

Get some ground beef, like 80/20 is good. Form into a patty, bigger and thinner than you think because it contracts and shrinks. Put in a frying pan on medium high, add salt and pepper. Flip when juices start coming through the top. Add salt and pepper. Add American cheese. Cook until cheese is melted.

By some nice buns. I like brioche. Toast them. Add whatever you want for toppings.

That's it. Don't overcomplicate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
American and burger enthusiast here, but i'm /fit/ is my opinion still valid?

Bun:
Can be a potato bun, buttermilk bun, sourdough bun, pretzel bun, kaiser roll or a plain white bun. As long as it's soft and the kind made for burgers then you're good, but I would personally advise against brioche for burgers since they're too rich for an already-rich burger.

cheese:
Cheddar is my personal favorite for burgers, but if you desire a better melting texture over flavor then you can use American cheese. Low-moisture mozzarella is also a super good melting cheese that works great on a burger. The excellent melting ability of low moisture mozz is why it's used in pizzas.

meat:
80% - 85% lean ground beef. thin or even smashed patties are better than big thick patties for burgers because you get more brown crust surface area, and you can stack multiple thin patties on top of each other with a slice of cheese on top of each one.
Do not salt or season your meat before cooking them or else they'll end up tough.

Fillings/sauce:
whatever you fuckin' want m8. I like my burgers plain with just the meat, cheese, and bun, but you do you.

Toast the inside part of the buns before assembling the burger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I love making smash burgers on my griddle (pic related)

Take two three ounce balls of at least 80/20 ground beef (70/30 is optimal)

Place them on a ripping hot cast iron, lay on top a thin film of parchment paper and smash them down with a metal spatula until they are paper thin

Season each patty with salt and pepper

Flip your spatula and carefully scrape each patty off the pan without removing any crust, then turn your spat over and flip the patty

Add a slice of American cheese to one patty (no other cheese will suffice, sorry), then place one patty on top of the other

Allow the patties to congeal, then set aside

Take a potato bun and drop it onto the still hot grill and mop up the rendered beef fat, then allow that to sit and build up a char on the bun, take off bun right before it burns

Assemble burger in the following order

bottom bun -> mayo or mayo based spread + other condiments -> pickles -> onions -> tomato -> lettuce -> burger -> top bun

If I'm in the mood to make a burger sauce I typically do a sauce consisting of:
mustard, mayo, hot sauce, pickle juice, finely minced pickles, smoked paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, and pepper to taste

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Get ground beef that's at least 20% fat. Portion into patties between 1/4 to 1/3 of a pound, around a quarter inch thick, or roughly the same diameter as your bun. Season liberally right before cooking; I like to use 3 parts salt, 1 part black pepper, 1 part garlic powder. Place on a very hot grill/pan/griddle with no extra fat and don't touch it until you start to see juices forming on the surface. Flip once and continue cooking till it's medium-rare, or no more than medium. If you're using cheese apply it after the flip. Lightly toast your buns for the last minute or so of cooking. There are a million different toppings and condiments, but the standard is lettuce, tomato, pickles (in that order, on top of the patty, not under). Virtually any condiment can work on a burger depending on the toppings, but the most basic is ketchup, mayo, mustard, or some combination thereof (though only using ketchup is kind of something only kids do).

make dirty rice by gently frying/toasting some basmati or jasmine in a skillet with a tiny bit of olive oil and whole cloves of garlic, add spices and then add twice as much water as to cover the rice to the skillet. cook covered for 20-30 minutes, stirring occasionally. wa la. it's a good recipe because you can just make a huge batch of the rice and store it in tupperware to use throughout the week.

>>18836039
I went vegetarian for about a year on two different occasions, another time maybe half a year. sometimes I was vegan, not on purpose but I don't consume much dairy as it is and sometimes I'll go long stretches without it for no particular reason.
>how did it affect you
the biggest impact was that it got me out of the mentality that a meal isn't complete without a slab of meat, or that meat itself can be the entire meal, and with that I got rid of a lot of bad eating habits. it made dropping all the goyslop much easier. physically and mentally I don't think it changed me that much but I sit in a chair 16 hours a day, maybe I would have noticed changes if I was more active
>would I try it again
sure, though I don't feel much of a need to. when I went back to eating meat the amount I ate was relatively small and that hasn't changed. it's mostly salmon and pork belly, and very rarely is it the focus of the meal (like some canned salmon on a salad, a bit of pork belly to flavor beans for burritos, etc.)
>go-to meals
salad, fried rice, rice & bean burritos or bowls, japanese style vegetable curry, bibimbap, pasta, really a lot of stuff I ate before, just without meat.
>meal planning
for a little while just to see what I was missing out of curiosity, but after that I just ate what I wanted. it's not like I wasn't already missing a ton of stuff while I was still eating meat
>supplements
no
>cheaper
for me, yes, but if you're still married to meat and have to have fake chicken nuggets and fake burgers and all that shit then you will probably spend more.
>interpersonal relationships
no. I dated meat eaters as a vegetarian and vice versa when I ate meat. the only people who 'can't' date someone with a different diet are the ones who turn their diet into their personality.

>>18836039
I am vegetarian, becoming an italist.
>How did it affect you? Would you try it again?
With you diet, you can think the way that your ancestors who ate a certain way did. Going back to the earliest man means eating raw, which I did. I felt so much better, I was never wrong and had such clarity of thought even though the ideas I got were so different from the mainstream that I was basically schizoposting in real life. Feel a "distortion" of this clarity whenever I eat meat and a dulling when I eat cheese. Going raw makes me need more sleep, I wake up early but I am asleep by 9pm.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
Impulse, just did what was easy. Converged on rice and beans with spices and no salt or oil (one batch for the whole week) before making the raw transition. Then I just ate carrots, fruit, and raw nuts.
>Did you need to take supplements?
I do not, goes against the whole thing the way I see it.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
If you are still going to cook, then yes. If you are eating raw, then no, grocery stores charge for nuts exactly like they are meat and veggies aren't cheap. This is a temperate zone problem only, though.
>Did it affect your interpersonal relationships? (Can't date a meat eater, couldn't eat out as much etc)
Old friends are sort of astonished and assume it takes some sort of discipline, which it doesn't after you stop making meat a daily habit. Family assumes that because of this, my not getting a booster shot, and smoking weed that I am no longer a good person. That is exagerrating, but it is hard not to view with suspicion people who view the burning of animal corpses as better and incomparable to burning a plant.

Only non-raw food I have now are some roasted nuts and also honey, which is not vegan. The seed oil may as well be cocaine to my system at this point, but I'm not gonna leave the nuts uneaten.

>ital
Raw veganism from the Caribbean, intertwined with the Rastafari movement. It is a spiritual science which posits that processed foods and meat are dead and therefore bad, and that the most healthy food is the purest, most unaltered, and natural food there is. Eating food filled with life increases your life force, while processed and animal-based meals deplete it. I have found it to be 100% true. Everything on the shelves in stores is basically poison, and most cultural staples consist of no real food by ital standards, just bread, dairy, salt, meat, and oil.

I sorta became a vegetarian inadvertently for about 8 months around the end of 2021. I was diagnosed with high blood pressure around that time as a mid 20s guy. It runs in the family but I was a fat fuck and I'm determined not to die an early death. I took a look at my diet and decided I needed to eat more vegetables and less processed junk.
>How did it affect you? Would you try it again?
The first 2 weeks were hell. I was fatigued, hungry and consistently wanted food. I wasn't satisfied. I started to realize that a bit of hunger was good for you, particularly if you want to lose weight. I decided on one cheat meal a week, and let me tell you that fast food was the best thing I've ever eaten. I then realized that fast food was an actual addictive substance. That's what I mean by sorta vegetarian, I'd eat a meat meal once a week. After those first 2 weeks I felt pretty damn good.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
Varied as much as possible. Salads, MANY vegetable soups over a small amount of rice, as much fresh vegetables as I could. Spaghetti squash is a fucking miracle food, I still eat it regularly. I'd get protein from beans and peanut butter.
>Did you need to take supplements?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Was a vegetarian during my most of my teenage years up until I was about 17. I was also a vegetarian for 49 days due to the death of my grandmother.
It takes about a week or two of getting used to, but after that, as long as you have resolve, you shouldn’t have any issues. You can still eat cheese and eggs unless you’re a vegan, so you really can have the vast majority of dishes by substituting. As I get older I would eventually like to go back to vegetarianism just for general religious reasons. I usually plan all my meals for the week when I go grocery shopping, and as long as you’re not a vegan you won’t need supplementation.
Good go to dishes: pasta, burrata salads, bruscheta, homemade nachos, mapo doufu, various noodle dishes, eggplant in garlic sauce, xifan, scrambled eggs, bean soups, potatoes, the world is your (vegetarian) oyster.

I was vegetarian for ~4 years from 2015 to 2019. Currently I eat 95% vegetarian.

>How did it affect you?
No noticeable effect to be honest.
>What were your go to meals?
Stews with beans and various pasta meals.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
I didn't cut out eggs or dairy so I didn't really give a shit about that stuff.
>Did you need to take supplements?
No. One of the oat milks I regularly use in cooking is enriched with B12 as well so even if I for some reason decided to become a vegan I'd probably not have to take any.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
Yes.
>Did it affect your interpersonal relationships?
No, I don't give a shit if you eat meat. Some people found it quite provoking but not to a degree that I actually lost anyone close to me. Nowadays finding vegetarian or even vegan meals when eating out is really not a problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18836039
Whole-food plant-based for almost four years now.
>How did it affect you? Would you try it again?
It made me conscious about what I eat and that led me to make a number of other lifestyle changes in the interest of my health and wellbeing, including quitting drinking, cutting out processed sugars and fats, and drinking tea. My health has improved greatly. My acne and asthma are gone. My mood and energy levels are much better, too. I can see myself being WFPB for the rest of my life.
>What were your go to meals?
I eat a lot of fresh fruit and steamed vegetables. I also make big smoothies with mango, strawberry, spinach, and dates. I love beans, chickpeas, and lentils, and I make a lot of MENA/Ethiopian dishes, like falafel or masir wat. I also eat a lot of edamame and tofu.
>Did you have to plan out your meals excessively to make sure you got a balanced diet, or did you decide based on impulse?
I eat on impulse.
>Did you need to take supplements?
Yes, I take a multivitamin to make sure I get enough iodine, zinc, copper, vitamin D, and vitamin B12.
>Do you think it's cheaper than an omnivorous diet?
Mine isn't, lol. I spend a lot on smoothie ingredients. But that doesn't mean a vegan diet can't be cheap and nutritious.
>Did it affect your interpersonal relationships? (Can't date a meat eater, couldn't eat out as much etc)
Carnies don't care that I'm vegan because I don't care if they eat meat or anything in front of me. I would prefer to date another WFPB vegan, though. Being vegan, especially WFPB, does make it much, much harder to go out spontaneously.

Are you thinking about making the leap, OP? I'd say just try it for two weeks and see how you feel.

>>18842335
That one is a supposed improvement on my mom's recipe, which was passed down from my late gran.
The original recipe calls for: chilli pepper, garlic, salt, sugar, msg, and coconut water.
That's it. It's the prepping of the meat that takes lots of time. The pork belly is washed, patted dry and seasoned with chillis, garlic, 15-20 sugar : 1 salt in a basin. Then let rest under direct sunlight for a whole day. (remember to use food wrapper). Then just cook under VERY low flame in 100% quality coconut water until the water becomes deep brown like a demi-glace.
What to expect from this dish? It's sweet, balanced with some salt and msg. The fat is almost translucent (thanks to sugar). It should be able to hold the meat together.
My recipe calls for extra steps in preparing the meat: The meat is seasoned and let rest like the OG. But then it is blanched from cold water with ginger until it sets its shape, then wash it. Dock the skin with whatever tool you have, and apply generous amount of salt, rub it, then pat it VERY dry.
Deep fry meat: fat, skin face down in just right amount of oil (only fat is fried). Once some of the fat is rendered, remove the deep fry oil and sear the meat on all sides until lightly brown with some scorching. Then, steam the meat on medium for 3-4 hours. After that, collect all the juice and fat and reserve meat in fridge. You can even smoke the meat by putting some smoking wood into the steaming water, and letting the water evaporate and burn the wood soot on purpose. I recommend having a dedicated steaming basin for this because it will get decimated.
Make coconut demi-glace with chilli pepper, garlic, salt, sugar, msg, and coconut water until thickened. Mix with steamed meat juice.
Pour demi-glace on meat, steam and serve.
The result from my recipe should be: less fatty, have a nice smokey flavour like how people in the countryside have it.

Depends on roast and density of the bean. The idea is to wait long enough that it'll brew consistently throughout the whole bag. You don't want an external variable(offgasing) throwing a wrench in the mix.
>Light roasts: 14+ days
>Medium-light to medium roasts: 10-14 days
>Medium-dark to dark roasts: 7-10 days

>>18845104
>Yeah this was my first bag
Ah cool - that makes sense, dialling in and punching out consistent espresso is a journey, not an end state, haha - but you've chosen a good place to start.
>No pressure gauge
So first thing's first, watch your shot time before you start making big moves on grind to chase channelling. The 25-30 second window isn't a hard and fast rule, but it does get you in the right place to make decisions on what to change later; if you're pulling a shot in that range and it tastes good and it's in the ratio you wanted and it's channelling towards the end that's both expected and perfectly acceptable. If it's channelling the whole time and you're pissing out a shot in 15 seconds then yeah it's better to try and chase down the channelling first.

How old is the coffee? Is it fairly freshly roasted or supermarket variety?

>>18838977
Those products aren't even available in the Old World, it's just the diaspora community struggling with americanized hedonistic decadence, same thing goes for all the Eastern Christians. Only Ethiopians don't have this problem from what I've seen.
From a Greek Orthodox perspective, as far as fasting goes, you either try to eat fast-appropriate food with greater or lesser effort, or you don't even try to fast. The religious rule of fasting exists to build character, primarily temperance and humility. Outside monastic communities it is not a strict law and more of an ideal, and for laymen it is usually considered enough to simply try your best. Not to get into the finer details, but there is also a strong tradition of vegetarian cooking which exists in order to properly celebrate religious feast days which occur during the fast. The food is meant to taste good, but it is very obviously lighter vegetarian cuisine.
Unlike the Catholics, fish is not licit during the fast (although it is seen as a "less-bad" food, in some places) and in fact in most places, the ideal fast excludes all dietary oils as well - which is by far the least-followed restriction among laymen for obvious reasons.
In this light, it is pretty clear where Beyond Meat and similar products belong. They are, at best, a "less-bad" food like fish, but fake meat products embody principles opposite to the ideal fasting food. The reason there is a "debate" is basically that disinterested laymen who might feel community pressure to fast will try to find loopholes in their daily life, and since the point of the fasting rule is humility, if you are another layman and not a priest it is considered counterproductive to insist and posture over the dietary rule that others are following, for the same reason that you aren't supposed to act prideful over people who don't fast. Still, I think it's pretty clear to everyone that this is a loophole.

Right dickheads, you're gonna see some real proper English food in here. Gets a bad rep in the rest of the world but that's because the rest of the world are fucking idiots.

We start with the humble pork pie, invented in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, which is actually my home county. It's a hot water crust pastry case filled with dense, roughly cut pork and fat, and then a bit of pork jelly to fill in the edges where it meets the pastry. There's really nothing much else like a pork pie, other pies don't taste the same. There's also the 'gala pie' which is basically the same but with an egg in the middle (nothing to do with a scotch egg)

its because the indelicate method for mass manufacturing orange juice is to

I use two wooden spatulas and stab the meat systematically left to right top to bottom until I eat the consistency I want. I don't really flip but just stab in short firm bursts.

posts.name: Anonymous

The only way for ground beef to be palatable is to simmer for at least 30 minutes in a little liquid BEFORE you actually use it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18843757
You have to break it up into smaller pieces while it browns. You do not do this by flipping, nor by moving it around. It's not wrong to do this, but it's not what the objective is. To break it up into smaller pieces you push the meat with the pointy end of a spoon/spatula into the bottom of the pan. So it breaks up.

>>18832487
If OP has dagnosed celiac, then that's that. There's a test, and it's final, and then the doctors put you on the diet. Then people started making gluten-free into a fad diet (along the same evolution of Atkins and other low-to-no-carb diets) and were claiming "Non-Celiac Gluten Sensitivity" or NCGS, which is a controversial phenomenon at best in the medical literature.

It's similar with keto, which is a legit diet that existed for decades as a treatment-of-last-resort for severe treatment-resistant epileptics (we're talking one step prior to cutting their brain in half here). Then, in the same line of genesis of low-carb diets from Atkins, it became reimagined for the general public as a fad diet, even though it has absolutely fuck all to do for the general population what its original intent was.

Arguably these medically-inspired fad diets have been a net good thing for society, as they have raised at least some bare minimal awareness for horrible diseases and the requirements some people need in daily life to live through them, and have made such requirements easier for those people to meet. And while the counterargument to that is that people cite gluten-free and keto pseudoscience to be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes, I'd argue that those people would be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes anyway. (The internet in general probably makes it worse, though).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18845741
It depends on the cut. Pork belly is very distinct from other meats because it's incredibly fatty and either made into bacon or used by Asians because it's really cheap. If uncured, it can be sliced and grilled or pan fried quite easily and makes a nice sandwich filling.
The loin is the more lean cut that's typically sliced into medallions with a small bit of fat to make pork chops. This cut is also better panfried or grilled but you must be cautious because the core loin is so lean that it's easy to overcook it and make shoe leather (hence why many adults don't like pork chops; their parents probably overcooked the loin into tasteless rubber to "get rid of the fat"). A favorite recipe of mine is lomo adobado, which is a whole pork loin that you marinate in a thick mix of quality paprika, crushed garlic, herbs, white wine vinegar, olive oil and lemon juice and then grill on a BBQ. Great dish to serve guests at a BBQ.
The hindquarters of pork are almost exclusively made into ham while you can often buy whole pork shoulder which is typically cooked as a roast with veg etc. a la roast beef or slow roasted to make pulled pork. Above the shoulder and across the neck is a tougher more marbled cut called the "butt" or "scallop" that is either cooked similarly to the shoulder, or minced to make sausage. Most pork sausages use meat from the butt and shoulder.
Finally you have the hocks: the ankles and lower legs of the pig. These are typically either boiled & roasted or slow cooked in a stew. Probably the cheapest cut and makes a nice stew because it has a large amount of connective tissue that thickens the broth, and the tough meat lends well to stewing.

t. butcherfag

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18846381
In general, pork lends itself better to marinating or curing than any other kind of meat. You can make bacon out of any cut of pork by wet curing it in brine and in some countries like Ireland they make bacon not only from the belly and loin, but the butt, shoulder and ham as well. Another very common flavour profile besides curing is fresh pork, mustard and apples; pork tends to have a very slight sweetness to it that is complimented greatly by sweet apples which is a combination found across the world. Other kinds of natural sweetness also combine well with pork, such as honey and brown sugar. Pork chops cooked with slices of apple and garnished with a strong mustard is a very traditional British dish that is quite tasty.
For Asian dishes, you can marinate pork in some mixture of oil, soy sauce, freshly chopped garlic & ginger. Like bacon, the sodium in soy sauce really enhances the pork's flavour which is then complimented by the garlic and ginger. Sliced pork belly marinated in this way and then grilled/fried and served with rice and steamed vegetables would make a nice Asiatic style dish.

dough is simple. you can either knead if you want (machines are useless if you're like me and like to have the dough for 10+ pizzas in your fridge) to be true to tradition or need exercise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
People posting about how homemade pizza is not worth the effort or it's not a good meal prep option are plain wrong. Here's the thing - all the ingredients can be prepared ahead of time and left in the fridge for days. Make a batch of dough, separate into several pieces (I make 4 at once), let them ferment in the fridge. Not only does the dough you made days ago lasts for about 6 days, it only gets better and better. Same with the sauce: buy a can of tomatoes, there should be enough sauce for about 10 small-medium sized pizzas, stores well for a couple weeks. Not to mention all the toppings: dry mozzarella, parmesan, pepperoni, onions, pepper and much more can be cut to size and stored in containers in the fridge for a long time.
In terms of cost, prices are different everywhere. I calculated the cost of my pizzas a few months ago, for a single pizza (out of batch of 12 from one can of tomatoes for sauce) it turned out to be under $1.5 for pizza roughly 25cm in diameter, which largely came from cheese - and I used a lot, could reduce by half and would still be great.
In terms of time, it's really just mixing the dough and cooking the sauce, which takes under half an hour for me, and then cutting up or shredding the toppings for a few minutes. Granted, I have to make dough two or three times to use all of the sauce, but it's not an issue at all. Making the pizza every day takes a couple minutes.
Dough recipe is important, as well as technique, but even the most basic homemade pizza would be great, and once you are comfortable with the basics, you can gradually improve. I make a lot of pizza at home since a few years ago, definitely over a hundred pizzas at this point, and I still improve something every time. But even the very first pizzas were very good and well worth the time, effort and money.

Uh. Are you retarded anon?

1) Don't buy pre-made dough. Fucking making dough is so easy, and it's fun, why would you not spend 5 minutes mixing flour, water and yeast together? Premade dough is the biggest scam, and it's disgusting.
2) 2kg of flour costs €2 and each pizza requires about 87 gram of flour, with 2kg you can make 25 pizzas or so. If you bought 25 in a restaurant, calculate the price. Here your flour would cost €2.
3) Buy canned tomatoes, costs like €1 and it's sufficient for at least 20 pizzas, maybe all 25. Total cost so far, for 25 pizzas, €3
4) The most expensive items, parmesan and mozzarella, if you want to go authentic. But you don't have to make a 100% authentic pizza, wtf, you are making it at home, just use whatever you have. €3 so far. Grate some regular cheese (not american or cheddar, use something normal). In Sweden, 1kg of what we call "household-cheese" costs like €14. It is enough to make 100 pizzas. Pic rel.
5) Add whatever toppings you have or want. Do you have chicken at home? Fry it and add. Scampi? Add. All these are relatively cheap proteins. Frozen chicken costs €14 and is enough for at least 15 pizzas.

So 5 steps. Lets calculate total cost:
Dough €2
Tomatoes €1
Cheese (for 25 pizzas) about €7
Protein (for 25 pizzas) maybe €20
€30 bucks, you make 25 pizzas.
Total cost for one motherfucking pizza? €1,2

How the fuck is this expensive?

i always make 8-10 or so balls and let them ferment, following 2-3 days i might use them to make a few pizzas and by day 3 i'll freeze them, i oil a zipper bag, get the dough ball out and put it in the bag. Then I put it on a plate so it retains its form and put it in the freezer. in a few hours, it's solid, i remove the plate and just keep the bag in the freezer

when its time to thaw just leave it on the counter or put it in water, it will retain its form in either way

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18843082
Pizza dough is best frozen before fermenting. So basically mix them, knead, shape into balls and freeze. When you pull them out of the freezer, defrosting and fermenting will take many hours, but the result is generally better than freezing after fermenting. But I don't freeze it anymore, I just make a few pieces at once and keep in the fridge for several days. This way the dough is more delicious and has better browning (but that's because there is more sugar from fermentation). The taste and convenience (lack of defrosting) is worth it for me.

>>18843167
No, pizza dough frozen after fermenting won't have as nice of an "oven spring", it won't rise as much in the oven. It's also not going to brown as much.
If you freeze before fermentation, you will certainly need quite a few hours for the dough to defrost and ferment, yes.
You can use any method, the differences are negligible at first. Just do what's more convenient for you, and later maybe try the other method.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18843392
You freeze the dough after mixing AND kneading it, which you conveniently forget about. It's not just flour, water and yeast that you freeze, it's the kneaded dough with gluten formed in it. And yes, the point of freezing the dough is to save time by mixing (and kneading) a single large batch rather than multiple smaller ones. And like I said, that difference (mainly in oven spring) is not a big deal, but it is there, both methods work fine though. They give approximately the same result and do the job of keeping the leftover dough for later. Try and make it both ways to compare, you will see the difference in the end result. You are arguing with someone who tried it both ways and also others while you clearly haven't tried any other method.

Semantics and translation issues? Salsa literally just means sauce in Spanish, but typically refers to chunkier or thicker spicy chili sauces in the u.s., with the word hot sauce typically referring to bottled and more watery chili hot sauce. That being said, though in Spanish salsa can mean any sauce, it typically refers to hot chili sauces, which can be further specified by saying salsa picante.

>>18832792
Not fun fact: out in the west (At least in Montana) they red pepper relish is apparently just not a thing. Like, for no reason. Zero supermarkets sell it- at most they'll sell red pepper jelly. The stores have literally every other Mezzetta brand jarred vegetable item (even literally jarred red peppers that you could turn into relish) but not the relish itself. I had zero clue when I wanted to make a sub one weekend and found it no where and got confirmation from a 55 year old Montanan I work with who has a pepper garden that it just isn't a thing here and he hated it too. Fast forward to a Jersey Mikes opening up near me and me being happy as fuck I can get a sub with red pepper relish again. These Montanan bumpkins proceed to get their mind blown after they try it and ask me why tf isn't this a thing here and I agree with them.

All hail the church of Red Pepper Relish. I'm converting as many as I can.

posts.com: Recommend Italian cuisine, both the dishes as they appear, and the recipes to make them. I want to start out with learning more about the food of the fine nation of Italy. As a bonus, feel free to recommend recipes which do not incorporate either tomatoes or dairy, or anything in general which would seem obscure or unusual to most Americans.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: chicago style pizza

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Everyday someone asks about italian recipes my goodness

>without tomatoes or dairy
Bruh be for real.


Hm.. pesto pasta can be made minus the cheese. You need olive oil, fresh basil, garlic, and pinenuts (baked). Blend it, cook with pasta. Very easy.

There's sandwiches, just minus the cheese again and I guess tomatoes. You need salami, panchetta, basil/lettuce, salt, pepper, olive oil, and if you want balsamic vinegar. It's like the real version of an italian bmt from subway. But please use fresh bread.

Meatballs, but without tomato sauce it's dry so why are you against tomatoes. You need grinded beef and pork, onions, egg, breadcrumbs, salt, pepper, and oil to cook. Make the balls and cook them, easy.

You can grill all kinds of vegetables, add them with olive oil, and eat alone or with pasta. Zucchini and eggplant are the major ones, bell peppers are good too.

Stuffed peppers, make a meat stuffing, some people add rice, hollow out bell peppers, add stuffing, bake. Look up a good recipe for you.

You can make a pizza without cheese, add oregano onto the sauce, or veggies if you want.

A protip for anyone thinking of copying this retard: when you brown beef or any meat as part of a stew, you have to remove it once it's browned and you start adding the onion and veg, otherwise you will overcook the meat into shoe leather esp. beef. Sear your cubed beef, remove it with a slotted spoon into a dish, cook and season the onions and veg in the juices and then throw it back in when you're about to cover it with stock/water.

First, I slit your throat, drain all the blood into a basin and make congealed boiled blood.
Second, disembowel. A nice, clean cut from middle of the chest downward, the guts should spill out splendidly. All the guts and organs are cleaned with heavy salt, starch and water. Special care for the intestines as they need to be turned inside out and cleaned, same for the stomach too. Organs are perfect for grilling, braising and stir fries.
Third, I chop, chop, and chop. Your brain shall make a fine soup, just like a pig's brain. Your arms, excellent for braising. Your belly? Too fatty, I will trim off the lean part to make meat loaf. The fat shall be rendered to make oil. All the muscles on the back? Slow smoke with hickory and maple. The ribs, I will chop them into pieces, marinate them, then steam on top of some thinly sliced mountain yam. The legs are for curing. Fingers, toes and neck, to make gelatinous soup. And the entire skeleton, exquisite, a nice golden brown broth.
Lastly, a feast shall be held for your family. They will eat you, and they will love it.

Is it actually good? They're opening one near me soon and I plan on trying it out. What should I order?

I'm making this thread because they've opened a bunch of Whataburgers in my city and it seems to be an extremely polarizing fast food place. Some people, especially those from Texas, claim it is literally the best fast food restaurant, and that you can't do better. Other people I've talked to have said it's okay, pretty decent, not bad, but nothing special. Which is true?

For the record I've had great Fast Food in my life. I just moved away from a place that had a Braum's, and I loved it. Is Whataburger at least as good or cheap as Braum's? Aside from that we have Culver's here and I think it's great. Freddy's is also okay but not as good as Culver's. Is Whataburger better than either of those? I've also had IN-N-Out on my journeys out west, and I think it's a fantastic burger for the price.

My internal ranking is that for fast food, Culver's and In-N-Out are the best. For the price, In-N-Out is definitely the best. I'd put Braum's at #3 for me personally.

But Whataburger seems to have advantages. They're 24 hours, they have a 12 hour all night/morning breakfast menu, and it seems like they might have some stuff that other places don't? I don't know, /ck/, what do I need to know about whataburger?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18841630
Homemade nut butters should be refrigerated once opened, you can tell if they spoil by their smell.
Jams/Jellies should always be refrigerated once opened.
Ketchup and Mustard are a little tricky because of the acidity and salt, but they still go bad much faster at room temp. If you're going through it fast you can probably keep it out.
The weirdest one is that Mayonnaise is shelf stable, but no one believes the manufacturers. It is terrifically easy to contaminate though, which is why most people prefer to refrigerate it.

All-Clad saucepans are very good, but do not hold their value on ebay at all. A D3 or D5 saucepan that would normally retail for $150 can regularly be found for $40-60 on ebay.

>>18842052
>>cast iron
>25$ for a single skillet
I have tried a number of them and here's my conclusions:
-Lodge are just fine. However, they are very annoying to use and clean. Lodge seasoning is extremely tough and nonstick, but because of the bumpy texture, you do get food stains that are difficult to clean off of the seasoning. Your spatula will make a lot of noise just brushing it across the surface and if any food burns/sticks, even just a small spot, then you just know it's going to be there the whole time you're cooking and that spot won't be nonstick anymore. I do not like using them.
-Finex/Stargazer/Butterpat/Field do not hold their seasoning very well. It just flakes off under normal use and there's no nice way to say it. If you think it's because some amateur is doing something wrong, using too much heat, not enough oil, then take a look at their websites and see the photos of the "owner of the company's collection." All their pans have splotchy seasoning. That's not to say they don't work for what they are, but it's distracting and annoying when your pan is constantly destroying itself. I do not like using these, and I've tried most of them.
-OLD skillets you buy from a flea market or ebay are the best. I don't know why this is, and you should strip the old seasoning (just soak in lye for a few days and it's easy) and re-season them yourself, but all of my old skillets, doesn't matter the brand, hold onto their seasoning, are easy to clean AND are really pleasant to use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18841630
Mold is the primary enemy when referring to refrigeration of items. Sealed items that have been pressure canned will last several years or more, depending on storage conditions. Once opened though, it is just a question of when mold growth will take hold.

Sauces and stuff that are handmade will last longer in the fridge, but it all boils down to how well you made the item (your cleanliness) and the mold environment of your house, plus the actual sauce contents (acidic, salty and alcoholic sauces will last way longer). They will eventually go bad, especially since homemade will lack preservatives.

If you are mixing premade sauces into a combo sauce, it should last several months in a covered container, or longer. Things like mayochup or whatever.

As long as you aren't making gallons of the stuff and use it semi-regularly, homemade sauces shouldn't go bad. Don't expect the sauce you jarred and threw in the back of the fridge for 3 years and forgot about it to be mold-free though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18844189
I don't think anon was talking about canning process.

If someone isn't canning their items which is a time-consuming process that requires sterilizing your instruments and containers for long-term storage, and they're just mixing a sauce together into a regular clean (but not sterilized) storage container (that isn't canned or vacuum sealed), they shouldn't bet on anything lasting more than two weeks in the fridge. Generally speaking people should treat most foods as lasting no longer than a week in the fridge unless if it is something really high in salt (soy sauce, worchestershire sauce, oyster sauce, etc), really high in sugar (jams, jellies, preserves, BBQ sauce), or pasteurized (most store-bought mayonnaise). One week or less is a good rule of thumb.

>>18844226
>Anything expensive is a up-sale by scammers. Copper this, alloy that, titanium this, all of it is scam in some form for richfags to flex with.
Copper is a good material for a saucepan. It promotes very even heating. A major drawback of cast iron is uneven heating. Pure stainless suffers from the same problem. Stainless pans need to have some sort of highly conductive material in between the cooking layer and the heating element to spread out the heat, whether aluminum or copper.

posts.sub: I always get egg shell in the pan when I crack my eggs
posts.com: How to avoid

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: buy nicer eggs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Don't pinch your fingers together when trying to open the egg after cracking, putting too much pressure trying to grab it will cause it to fragment, you only want to pull outward with as little force inward on the shell as you can manage

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: crack the egg and then do it like you are tearing the shell apart to two halves, but pour it via the opposite side, not where you hit it, the other side will be torn clean and have no shell pieces

Crack on a flat surface

At the moment however it seems in my area that Trader Joes (same company) has Aldi beat in egg prices, probably because Aldi has yet to figure out its supply chains for the cage-free eggs legally mandated in several states.

>>18827998
Aldi can get away with it because 1) they've been doing it forever, everywhere around the world; 2) their prices on all goods are so much lower than anyone else's; and importantly:

3) if it's your first time at Aldi and you were caught off-guard by the cart thing, that doesn't actually stop you from browsing and shopping if you want to. Compare Sam's or Costco, where they check membership at the door -- you cannot even browse if you are not a member, so the casual person who looks at a giant store where people are coming out with lots of groceries and thinks, "hey, let me check out the prices," would surely be offended more at the fact he *cannot* check out the prices. Yet somehow Costco not only survives but thrives. Being "in the know" about Aldi's different culture can actually be enticing to some people, without being exclusionary -- though maybe it would help their sales even more if they made it exclusionary.

Same in my state (MA), even though it allows groceries to sell alcohol in general, but with some limitations, namely that the alcohol must be sold in a separate section with its own cashier. >>18827079
>The name Champagne on a Cognac bottle refers to its origin, namely the growth area the grapes were grown in. There are six growth areas–or “terroirs”–in total, and the two that are considered to produce the finest eau-de-vie are named Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. These two premium terroirs have soil that compares to the soil of the Champagne region in Northern France. Hence the shared name.

>A Cognac is called a “Fine Champagne Cognac” when it contains a blend of eaux-de-vie from both Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. At least 50% of the blend have to be from the Grande Champagne. When the word Champagne is used on a Cognac, it will either be preceded by the word, Grande, Petite, or Fine. This simply denotes the terroir in which the grapes were grown.

>>18829472
I typically use a chefs knife; I score a line where I need the cap to separate from the bottle by gently running the blade around the circumference where the bottom of the bottle cap meets the glass, then I use the back of the knife to crack the wax. Don’t worry about damaging the cork, the cork itself is attached to a plastic cap and there’s no need to remove the wax from the cap. See picrel, that’s my 1982 Delord. I’m pretty OCD so I gun for a clean cut as pictured since I like my bottles looking nice. This takes experience though. The first time you do it you’re gonna be messy, so do it on a big empty table or kitchen top where you’ve got plenty of space so you can subsequently wipe all the chipped pieces of wax off with ease. Enjoy!

Oh and re: the ABV, it’s honestly fine. Most Armagnac is ABV’d @ 40% (you can get higher), and I’ve had some pretty solid whisky at 40% even though I generally lean a wee bit higher for my favourites. I just had my Delord with my partner and we both agree no cheese or mushroom in the nose, palate and finish, lol. Looking at my tasting notes though, this is what I wrote: nose: extremely grape-y, like sniffing a well packed bouquet of fruits and berries packed in a basket held together by UHU glue; palate: sweet, minty and clinical, hard to pinpoint individual flavours, there’s something synthetic about the flavour but in a way I very much enjoy, it just tastes super clean; finish: the synthetic part really comes out here, plasticky but damn it’s addictive (bits of the UHU glue nose come out here on your taste buds, and just like UHU glue, it’s god damn addictive). This definitely won’t be everyone’s cup of tea, but god damn am I always in a heightened state of zen whenever I take my shot from this bottle.

I typically don’t ever leave a bottle open for more than three months so I don’t have an issue with ageing becoming a problem. I typically drink one shot a day with my significant other (we do have one or two breaks a week though), sometimes we share one shot, sometimes we have a shot each; so with my rule of four open bottles at once that pretty much guarantees each bottle will finished within three months. I devised this rule mostly because for whisky it can be very unpredictable how well a bottle ages, and in my experience it’s not uncommon for shit to go downhill fast once the bottle is about 50% empty with all that air mucking about inside. Funnily enough I find Armagnac holds much better than whisky; I once had a bottle open for over a year and I still thoroughly enjoyed it. But like my current Glenfiddich 15 VAT 03 that’s open, I can tell I’m enjoying it a wee bit less now that the bottle is down to its remainder 35%. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18833006
Kek. In my shithole (Singapore) alcohol is taxed at a fixed value per litre or alcohol, not percentage. The sheer irony is that this basically means our alcohol tax is a poor people’s tax more than anything because for cheaper shit you pay a higher percentage in tax (since the product is cheaper but the tax is fixed): thus the more expensive your liquor the more meaningless the tax becomes (you pay the same $ per litre regardless of whether you’re buying a 20$ piss wine or a 1000$ or fuck it 10000$ bottle of scotch). Beer is thus pretty damn costly here (we’re one of the most expensive countries to buy beer in), but once you go into the 3-figure range like I dunno a Dewar’s 32, it’s often cheaper here than in Europe.

Kilchoman Machir Bay, Port Askaig, Port Charlotte, Scarabus, Islay Gold, Smokehead. these are all very straightforward Islay single malts and everything except Kilchoman is produced by Caol Ila.

as for ranking it's like a hybrid of Highland peat level but not heathered, but briney and peppery like Old Pultney. not on par with stuff from the shores of Kildalton. if you're just getting into Islay dont forego Laphroaig Select or Ardbeg An Oa or Lagavulin 8.

Haagen-dasz is the only good brand of premium ice cream widely available that I've seen have only the required ingredients of ice cream, i.e. is actual ice cream.
Blue Bell, Ben & Jerry's, Enlightened, and all these other brands are ALL guar gum/vegetable gum/gum arabic added frankencreams.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18842953
>How does age effect liubao.
In my humble opinion liubao requires at least 3 or more years of ageing in the general area that it produced (high humidity) before it really becomes liubao. That high humidity aging really gives the liubao its classic taste profile of wood and soil notes and that sort of root celler vibe and smooth drinking character. That said younger liubao or those that are aged somewhere drier like Kunming can be good too, they have a tendency to have more bitter and chocolate notes and maybe a sort of closer to ripe puer flavor profile. Anyway liubao is great, i think its generally better than ripe puer, at least in my experience.
Aged matters less with ripe puer, a couple years anywhere for the pile taste to air off some, preferably its aired loose leaf for a year or two before pressing. But after that aged makes a subtle difference unless we are talking hong kong traditional storage or some other very humid ageing environment. Older ripe (early 2000s and older) tended to be less heavily fermented and required a longer period of aging to reach a good taste profile and get out the pile notes. Modern ripes are rarely made that way and when they are they are typically fermented more carefully so they don't require the same aging period to be drinkable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
drinking two GABA oolongs today, might as well make a brief comparison

unroasted Si Ji Chun GABA oolong:
>scent: spices (cinnamon?) and maybe some honey
>taste: pears, spices, creamy, autumn leaves, some sweetness but also sourness / acidity. mild with no bitterness
>brewing: really easy to brew grandpa style. never gets bitter at all, it gets sour instead. I find this to be typical of GABA teas

roasted Jin Xuan oolong:
>scent: freshly baked cookies with spices. perhaps slightly burnt cookies
>taste: strongly roasted, cookies present but oddly not very sweet, butter, smoky roasted finish. a little one-note
>brewing: I find this is a bit less suitable for grandpa style, just because it can get really roasty. maybe I just need to figure out the proportions better

Tea is perishable and only ever gets worse with age, never better. If it benefits from aging it's simply inferior material.

I remember one time in middle school they made some turkey shit-on-a-shingle (there wasn't a written menu, so I don't know what their name for it was) that wasn't part of the normal rotation and it was shockingly good. Nothing else really jumps out in my memory, but I generally enjoyed the cafeteria food while everyone else bitched and moaned relentlessly. I even liked those shitty gray burgers.

Now the college dining halls had some good shit, even if the quality probably wasn't actually much better in reality. There was this chicken tortilla soup that was superb. I'd completely stuff myself on it every time it showed up. And they had this stir fry station where you'd put together a bowl of ingredients that they'd dump it into a wok and then you'd pick a sauce for it. Normally it was mediocre, but twice a week they'd switch it up for a pasta stir fry where they'd use the woks to stir fry pasta and vegetables with a pasta sauce (either marinara or alfredo or a 50/50 mix if you knew to ask). You could load it up with chicken/sausage/meatballs and onion and mushroom and spinach and so on and it'd all end up browned and caramelized and perfectly coated in the sauce. Absolutely delicious.
The crazy part is that they had the same tortilla soup and a similar pasta fry station at two completely different colleges I went to. I should've found out who they were buying that soup from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18844675
>Ew, is that actually good? Sounds like a shitty vodka sauce.

It was surprisingly good. The acidity of the red sauce cuts through the richness of the white sauce. Being tossed around in the nuclear hot wok probably had some effect too. It's a bit crude maybe, but tasty.

>Mine had two and they were both stocked with all kinds of good stuff. Fresh sushi whenever you want. We even had a 7/11 or something like it built into one of the commons.

That's basically how it was a UIUC. Every cluster of dorm buildings had a shared dining hall and little convenience store full of snacks (some also had little concession stand things in the stores). The way the meal plans worked is that you'd get X amount of dining hall entries per week and Y amount of credits you could either spend at the store or for another dining hall entry. The credits were roughly equivalent to 1 credit = $1 at the store and I believe dining hall entry was 10-15 credits (total rip off). If I recall correctly the plans were something like:

>Infinite dining hall entry, 0 credits
>12 dining hall entries, 15 credits
>10 dining hall entries, 45 credits
>No dining hall entries, 130 credits

The trick was that credits would roll over into the next week, but dining hall entries didn't. So I found that the 10/45 plan was the best because it gave you the most flexibility. There were plenty of days where I'd only go into the dining hall once because I'd buy lunch at the student union building between classes, so 10 entries per week was plenty for me. Meanwhile, $45 at the store per week was a fuckton and it was almost difficult to spend it all. I was fucking loaded on snacks and I ended up storing most of the excess value in 12 packs of soda. I practically had a wall of Cokes at the end of each semester.
Good times.

>>18844826
>if you're a pro chef, may i ask for a recommendation for cake recipes? specifically a chocolate cake, a pumpkin cake, and a carrot cake.

okay sure brother.

for chocolate cake I usually do em tiny, spongey and layered. look into a good sponge cake recipe and modify with cacao solids and cocoa butter. if you make a ganoche and coat the chocolate cake it develops a soft, almost leathery shell after you pop it in the fridge. retains moisture good and is very tasty. top with pistachios.

i've never made pumpkin cake but as far as flavors go, i'd spice it heavily with anise, cardamom, nutmeg, cinnamon, and mace- i'd recommend you make it denser as well, nice and moist. use less eggs and only the yolks to achieve this.

carrot cake can actually take a lot of cinnamon, I recommend you make it somewhat moist, and coat the edges of the cake pan with butter, and brush maple syrup on. this makes the cake moist but not dense due to the formation of a caramelized shell on the exterior

>And what's your opinion on this?
That's a decent technique, but my process for doing what you're trying to achieve is to sear and then flambe the meat with liquor in a very very hot pan very fast, and then cook it low and slow. The reason for this is the sear locks in the moisture when you're doing it low and slow. You can control the moisture of the "crust" by basting with either it's own juices, or with a sauce made by deglazing the pan you seared the meat in with a complementary wine.

>Also I never add pepper to my steaks before I cook them because it burns
Sometimes I do if it's coarse, fresh ground pepper and i'm massaging it into the steak prior to cooking, but typically I add it to the pan toward the end of cooking the steak, because the heat opens up the flavor of the aromatics, and it's less likely to burn.

Hope this helps. I'm actually getting featured by the university that contains the wine and beer bar I work at. Starting to get notorious.

It's not some big coincidence. Pogs were started in Hawaii and were named after the POG drink. It was before my time, but POG apparently used to come in glass bottles back in the day and there was a little piece of cardboard with the label on it under the screw on top, and those where the original POGs. Then in the early 90's (when I was in elementary school in Hawaii) some school teacher reintroduced the game and it quickly spread to the other islands and eventually the mainland. So yeah, POG pogs were really common. Then again, they made pogs for fucking everything. I remember I used to have one with a picture of Saddam Hussain on it that said, "Hit me, I deserve it!" and I had no clue what it even was because I was 7 and what is this. It's funny thinking back to pogs. We were literally playing with marbles before that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18835210
If you get charcoal just get a Weber kettle, the one with the fancy ash catcher is nice, but the cheaper one with the bullshit plate ash catcher does the job.

Go to Costco and get kingsford pro charcoal. You can usually get it on sale for 13-15 bucks for 40lbs. Also, just get the paraffin wax cubes to start the charcoal. Put it in a pyramid, walk away for 20 minutes and prep whatever you want and come back when the coals are ashed over and knock them down. Lighter fluid is awful and makes your food taste awful. Chimney starters work great, but you need welding gloves to pick one up that's started.

If you're interested in smoking meat as well as grilling, I would get a Pit Barrel. It's brainless to operate and the results are fantastic, plus you can use it as a grill.

I have an MHP Nat Gas grill which is great for basic grilling, and it's 30 years old, but they are also > 1000USD new. It's super convenient and I never run out of gas, but there's no satisfaction in using it.

Whatever you do, avoid buying chink shit from walmart or home depot, it will crap out within 18 months.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If this is your first grill go with propane. It's less work and you can control the heat more easily. Goes from cold to cooking temp in 5-10 minutes vs 30. Less cleanup, no ashes full of hot coals to deal with. Charcoal may have a slight edge when it comes to flavor but most of the time not worth the extra effort.

You know you're supposed to sear the meat after the fact, right anon? The sous vide just makes sure the cut's medium rare (or however you want it) the whole way through. >>18844649
Corn on the cob. It's all we grow, but we have no cornbread tradition unlike the East and South, and we have no masa tradition (for white people) like the Southwest and Latin America, so we just boil the shit out of the cobs and eat it with butter.

Also cold cereal, since we have corn and wheat and milk here. Pancakes too I guess, but with fake flavored corn syrup instead of real maple syrup (it was prohibitively expensive for everyone I knew growing up until relatively recently).

Above all, Midwesterners are thrifty. "Nothing's too good for my family" does not apply when real maple syrup's even 3x more expensive than imitation, much less 6x like it is or 10x like it used to be. Fresh herbs -- in this economy? Fancy cooking techniques? Who's got the spare time when Single-Mom's got her gym date tonight and there's plenty of generic-brand TV dinners?

When you're in the Chicago area you get a lot of Polish and Mexican cuisiine, and in the Wisconsin and Indiana area you get various Eastern and Central European and Alpine traditions popping up, but apart from that I've covered the general idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18845419
The Midwest is where corn and soy mostly, and to a lesser extent wheat and dairy, are produced in insane abundance -- mostly for animal feed but a teeny tiny fraction goes to human consumption (fun/interesting/depressing road trip game when driving thru Midwest farm country is to try and spot a farm that produces human food). Thus corn on the cob and cold cereal is our "native"/"local" food. This is also reflected in quite a bit lower costs for eared corn at grocery stores in Midwest cities, since the net transportation cost is much lower, which thus would increase consumption at the table. Indeed, when my family first moved to the U.S. and lived in subsidized housing in the Midwest, corn on the cob cookouts were the staple summer BBQ meat substitute for the building complex. (This again is not atypical, but percentage-wise against other produce, eared corn was much cheaper in that Midwest city than it is in my current East Coast city; that can also reflect the proportionate reduction in ag subsidies over time since I lived there, however.)

Regarding cheap supermarket stuff, the thrifty Midwesterner is a common stereotype, that you can easily confirm anywhere in current online culture and in back news and scholarly archives with good search skills. Many people are thrifty, and many groups of people have thrifty or cheap stereotypes, but Midwesterners as a regional group have that specific stereotype that East-coasters, West-coasters, Appalachians, Southerners, Texans, etc etc etc don't have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18845665
Corn is generally cheaper, yes, but I think you're overemphasizing it. Corn of the cob and cereal are very pan-american things. No one would say either is a distinctly midwestern thing and I don't think I've ever seen a midwesterner try to claim they are.
As for the thriftiness thing, seems like a meme. There's walmarts and costco's everywhere (in fact, they're more densely concentrated on the coasts) along with lazy lower to middle-class moms buying cheap garbage.
My point is that neither of these things are meaningfully unique to the midwest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18842622
>Do people take cross contamination too seriously nowadays?
yes

although, you can't base anything on those cooking shows. that's not real foodservice. it's theatrical.

Meat from large producers is very safe because it has strong HAACP controls protecting consumers. Chicken produced by Tyson, for instance, is monitored by USDA inspectors on site and tested multiple times throughout production runs for pathogens. If anything is detected, the run is scrapped up until the last negative test, everything is sanitized, and production will only resume when it tests negative for pathogens. Safe handling procedures from production to transportation ensure food safety to an error margin within 1:10000000. You would be absolutely fine chomping down raw chicken from any large producer.

On the other hand, as any who gets USDA/FDA updates is aware of, things like leafy greens that aren't as heavily regulated and hard to sanitize are responsible for much more instances of foodborne illness. Most people don't think twice about cross contamination when it comes to spinach or lettuce in their salads and their washing techniques are woefully inadequate.

All of that being said, foodborne illness is pretty rare. You should maintain good practices, but don't lose any sleep over anything.

posts.com:
>>18842622
>Do people take cross contamination too seriously nowadays?
Yes. It's the classic trope of people taking good practices to extremes. Like when people wash their hands every hour because "bacterias are bad".

The amount of bacterias that reside in a bad chicken far surpass the amount of bacteria you transfer from an uncontaminated chicken onto your utensil, which you will likely wash shortly thereafter anyway.
Salt kills bacteria, so you shouldn't be afraid of sticking your hand there anyway.

When you are cooking (at home mind you, different practices in restaurants) you can use the same knife because you are going to cook the food anyway. You will not spawn bacteria in the 15 minutes you spend cooking the food, nor will you transfer a significant amount of bacteria from the chicken to the broccoli if you use the same knife. You are going to cook the broccoli anyway. There is no need to be afraid. Your food is not poison.

The problems begin if you don't clean after yourself. Wash your utencils, but also clean the surface. If you don't clean your surfaces, in due time, there will be bacteria development. That is the biggest hazard at home. Cross contamination as you are cooking for your family is a not an issue whatsoever.

>you have better temperature control in a dutch oven and you can sear the meat in it beforehand as well.
You miss the point in epic fashion. One, you can brown the meat in any pan. Two, and way more importantly, the point is convenience. >>18842885
>thinking you need a recipe for a slow cooker
Any ordinary recipe also works in a crock pot - not just that, you don't even strictly NEED a recipe. If you just throw in stuff on feel and let it simmer, it'll probably work.
As for ordinary recipes, you either adjust it by adding less water, by adding a cornstarch or flour sludge, or by doing both. Curries are the easiest shit you've ever seen in a good old Crocker, and it'll tenderize a fat chicken thigh to boot without any need to do prep work. Crock Pots are only limited by your imagination.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18842885
Crockpots are useless counter space hogs outside of their one purpose: taking shit to potlucks to keep them warm. The only advantage to them is they take 8 hours+ to make shit, so you can start something at night and have it ready in the morning to take to the potluck. They also do work to start shit in the morning and have dinner ready when you come home.

Realistically, you are better off with a instapot. They do rice, soups, beans, and meats, and all in FAR less time. Plus you can sear stuff, which is important to proper soup and sauce production. Crock pots do not sear. So they will be inferior to both normal stovetop and instapot type devices.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18843959
It is better to leave stock unsalted and without extras so you have max flexibility to use it in recipes. A lot of meals do use alcohol as a component, but you should add it at assembly time, not to the stock so you can preserve the deglaze properties & flavors of the alcohol and so you can pick the type needed for the recipe.

>>18843445
yeah no that's not how it works at all. fat = juicy and tender meat. movement = tough, lean meat with lots of flavour. If you want flavour you get cuts from old animals that moved a lot: tails, paws, neck, jaws - and you simmer them for ages. There's absolutely no reason to pay 100s for Wagyu, on the contrary: there are dozens of quality marbled races out there (Simmental, Holstein, Rubia Gallega, Montbéliard, Jersey,...) at 1/10th the price with better flavour. Cows don't need massages to improve flavour. They need to move. Don't get fooled again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I work at a bakery where i make all the cookies. Most are basic but we have a couple specialties that are pretty good.

Chocolate crunch (not actually crunchy)

5lb powdered sugar
6oz cocoa powder
1oz salt
4lb finely chopped pecans
1lb12oz egg whites

Sift together sugar, cocoa and salt and mix well by hand. Add toasted pecans fresh out the oven and mix again. Beat egg whites to a meringue while toasting pecans and add after them. Load batter into piping bag and dispense onto sheets in blobs about 1.5tbsp each, count on them spreading to about 2" diameter . Bake at 325 for 10m (ymmv without commercial convection oven). Yields about 260 cookies.

"Cocoons"

8lb sugar
8lb shortening
4lb liquid eggs
4oz salt
7.5lb cake flour
7.5lb pastry flour
4.5lb finely chopped pecans

Mix like you you would any other cookie dough. Cream sugar and shortening, add egg, add flour, add salt and pecans. Roll lengths of dough into cylinders about 1" in diameter. Cut cylinders into 1" pieces and roll them into rough balls by hand or use a 60 year old wooden jig like i do. Drop balls onto pans as tight as you like, they won't spread much. Bake at 325 for 9m. Yields about 1400 cookies. I coat them in powdered sugar for the store but i prefer them without. I also use the same dough for chocolate thumbprints and turtle cutouts with chocolate "shells".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To make kimchi using ingredients that are more commonly found in Western cuisine, you will need to make some substitutions. Here is a basic recipe to get you started:

Ingredients:

1 head Napa cabbage, thinly sliced
1/4 cup kosher salt
1 cup water
1/4 cup gochujang (Korean chili paste)
2 tablespoons rice vinegar
1 tablespoon granulated sugar
2 cloves garlic, minced
1/2 teaspoon ginger, grated
1/4 cup green onions, thinly sliced
Instructions:

In a large bowl, mix together the cabbage and kosher salt. Add the water and toss to combine. Let the cabbage sit for 2 hours, or until it has wilted and released some of its liquid.
In a separate bowl, mix together the gochujang, rice vinegar, sugar, garlic, and ginger.
Drain the cabbage and rinse it thoroughly under cold running water. Press out any excess liquid.
Add the cabbage to the bowl with the gochujang mixture and toss to combine.
Add the green onions and toss again.
Pack the kimchi into a clean glass jar, pressing down on it to remove any air bubbles.
Let it sit at room temperature for 24 hours, and then transfer it to the refrigerator.
Your kimchi will be ready to eat after a few days, and it will keep for several weeks in the refrigerator.

Note: You can also use other vegetables such as carrots, radish, and onion as well, but you may need to adjust the recipe based on the vegetable you use.

>>18835618
>Whiz is traditional
Except whiz wasn't invented when cheesesteaks were first made. Whiz was first added by Geno's to cater to Midwestern tourists who were dismayed that Pat's didn't serve theirs with the Whiz and Velveeta they were used to. After Geno's exploded in popularity with tourists, Pat's was forced to follow suit or go under. It got so bad for Pat's that all of their satellite locations had to close, leaving only the original one at 9th and Passyunk in South Philadelphia. They had a location on South Street, another on Ridge Ave in Roxborough/Manayunk and a third somewhere in Southwest Philadelphia (forgot where). The Ridge Ave location is sorta still open, but on Henry Ave and under different ownership, now called d'Alessandro's. The Ridge Ave location is actually where cheesesteak was first made in the late 1950s, several years before Whiz was even invented never mind sold in stores. Prior to that, it was just "steak sandwich" with no cheese.

>you'll get made fun of if you don't
No.

>>18835597
Any take away pizza joint in South Philly. If you're already close to Pat's/Geno's, J&J is about a block up 9th street from there and made decent cheesesteaks last time I was there over 15 years ago. Otherwise, don't go out of your way for one. Really, just about any place that isn't Pat's, Geno's, Oregon, Tony Luke's, Jim's or Phil's will be good.

>prov or whiz
Depends what you like. Whiz is for tourists and people from Northeast Philadelphia (IE tourists) and provolone is traditional while non-white people tend to prefer American cheese.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18845289
It’s not hard if you don’t mind bulk purchasing that will average out to $50/week or less, but may cost more up front
>meats
Pork and chicken are dirt cheap as is ground beef. Offal meat is often in its own bargain section and gloriously good for you. Buy bulk packs, buy large family packs of stewing meat and use it to make stews and sauces shredded bbq style food and more. Ham is dirt cheap too.
>carbs
Potatoes and rice are dirt cheap in bulk, flour can be dirt cheap too if you want to make your own breads or pastas.
Dry pasta in bulk is dirt cheap.
>vegetables
Carrots, cabbage, onions, are all purchasable in bulk packages for a few dollars at most. They can be eaten raw, cooked in a variety of ways and seasoned any way from Mexican to Chinese. Basically any root vegetable costs nothing, and only bullshit trendy veg like cauliflower is expensive to capitalize on dumb yuppie faggots.
>fruits
I’ll be honest and say I don’t eat much fruit so I can’t give great advice but I know frozen fruits are very inexpensive and make for good smoothies if that’s your thing.
And don’t forget canned items and especially bulk packages of beans.
To keep life fun just vary out the spices you use. Make a Mexican style pork chop and corn one day and a Chinese chicken and cabbage stir fry the next.

>>18844721

EASY AND DELICIOUS FRENCH DRESSING. TRY IT! YOU WILL NOT BE DISSAPOINTED.


COMBINE

1TBS DIJON MUSTARD
1TBS GOOD WHITE WINE VINEGAR
1 FINELY MINCED GARLIC CLOVE
SALT AND PEPPER TO TASTE

SLOWLY DRIZZLE 4 TBS OF EXTRA VIRGIN OLIVE INTO WHILE STIRRING

KEEP STIRRING UNTIL EMULSION IS FORMED.

ADD 2 TSP OF WARM WATER TO THIN.

ADD TO SALAD DRESSING.


DO NOT TELL ME YOU DON'T APPRECIATE A PROPERLY SEASONED BOWL OF LEAVES AND VEGETABLES.

A good salad dressing needs to be an emulsion because then the acidity, seasoning, and oil evenly coat everything instead of having just the oil coat the lettuce and the vinegar with the seasoning slide off and go to the bottom of the bowl.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18844460
You can't treat it like normal pasta and dump any kind of sauce on it. It has to be used in the right dish or recipe. It's also easy to overcook.

Basically: it's delicate and finicky, and you can turn it into a gross mess if you don't use it correctly.
I think you just need to add enough salt to keep it from sticking to itself. Not too much, though. And you also need to pay attention to it and stir it regularly so it doesn't self-clump. I think you also need to avoid over-crowding it in the pot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was dicing onions for a stew. I make big batches of food at a time, and thus I chop a lot of onions. I was dicing the onions and half listening to music when I began to wonder how much time in my life I spent cutting onions in some way.
I cook most days, most of these meals will involve onions at some point. I use 100s of onions in a given year. How much time have I spent over a cutting board with my knife slicing onions.
Then I started to think about how I'm just a home chef. I'm not even fancy, I just like cooking. How much time does an actual professional cook spend chopping onions? I have to imagine that some intro level chef is spending 8 hours a day chopping onions someone in France. My god, what a life that is. So much time spent just preparing food.
But then, I thought about how sometimes I get irritated about having to chop onions, but in the moment of my onion dealings I don't actually mind it. My mind is focused on the task and I just execute. Execute. Execut.
And that made me think about the fun of food preparation. When I'm not cooking, sometimes I have to kind of force myself to start cooking, but once I'm going my mind is focused, and I just sort of deal with what's in front of me. After the fact, I look back and feel like it took awhile. Before the fact, I don't necessarily want to cook. In the moment though, it's rarely bad. I enjoy it.

Cooking is fun. I love onions. Pic unrelated.

Guanciale/Pancetta, maybe salted pork if I don't have the former. Pecorino Romano for the sauce, Parmigiano for the seasoning. Lots of black pepper. I add about 2 cloves of garlic and small helping of butter when cooking the meat. I make my sauce using whole eggs, cause I can't bring myself to waste all of the whites. I also like to add chopped spinach to garnish.

>>18839499
Personally I start with cooking the guanciale. I'll start boiling my water for the pasta after the the guanciale is started. That way the guanciale is finished and the pan is removed from the heat for a few minutes before the pasta is ready to add. Be mindful of the heat in the pasta and water, it's enough to scramble your eggs. Better to start low and work your heat up to the desired outcome rather than try to rush through your sauce.
